translation.text: Raamkalee, Fifth Mehl:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

translation.text: The body is a patch-work of threads.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

translation.text: The muscles are stitched together with the needles of the bones.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

translation.text: O Yogi, why are you so proud? ||1||

translation.text: The patched coat of the body shall last for only a few days. ||1||Pause||

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. text: ਨਾਥੁ ਛੋਡਿ ਜਾਚਹਿ ਲਾਜ ਨ ਆਵੈ ॥੨॥

translation.text: Abandoning your Lord Master, you beg from others; you should feel ashamed. ||2||

transliteration.text: nāth shōd jāchah lāj n āvai .2.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

translation.text: Your consciousness is restless, Yogi, as you sit in your Yogic postures.

text: ਗੁਰ ਗੋਰਖ ਕੀ ਤੈ ਬੂਝ ਨ ਪਾਈ ॥

translation.text: You do not understand Gorakh, your guru.

transliteration.text: gur gōrakh kī tai būjh n pāī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. text: ਹੁਣਿ ਪਾਇਆ ਗੁਰੁ ਗੋਸਾਈ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ਦੂਜਾ ॥੨॥੧੩॥

translation.text: finds the Guru, the Lord of the World, in this life. ||1||Second Pause||2||13||

transliteration.text: hun pāiā gur gōsāī .1. rahāu dūjā .2.13.
